bibl.title: Letter from [Gustaf E. Lambert] to [Albert E. Truby?], [19--]

div1.p: [Lambert] answers twenty-one questions dealing with the yellow fever experiments at Camp Lazear. He describes how he assisted with the care of the patients, the work of female nurses, his involvement with the sanitary work, and an incident in which he broke quarantine to get Ames' help with his patient, Andrus.

div1.head: Letter from [Gustaf E. Lambert] to [Albert E. Truby?], [19--]

and put them back in bed then
took hold under his arm and laid
him back in beddhe was not

10) Not at the hospital but he did an

11) I don't know

13) yes Sir About Sept 15 Dr Ames
came to me and asked me if I would
go down and take care of a patient
that was coming in I reminded Dr
Ames
4
about having been in quarantine
7 1/2 month at No1 during which time
I lived in the office building of the
yellow fever section. I might just as
well tell now how it happened that
I landed in that bad place. One morning
at roll call Maj. Carter came out and
asked if there were any one who
would voloter volunter to go out
on sanitary work, I folishly wispered
to the man on my left, I wouldn't be
afraid to go if I were detailed, and
without a seconds hesitation he stepped
forward held up his hand and said,
Maj. here is a guy who wants to go
Maj. Carter asked me if I were afraid
of yellow fever I said no (but I am
afraid I did not tell the truth) I was
then told to report to Dr Ames. I did
so and was taken down to the palace
where I looked after the cleaning gang,
scraping all walls and ceilings then
5
spraying, floors were washed with
a 50-50 muriatic acid and water.
In late fall when yellow fever brook
out at headquarters Dr Ames said
now I'll see if you are afraid of
yellow fever, he gave me a list of
things needed and told me to go
back to the hosp present the list to
Maj. Carter for approval and then go
to ware house and bring the things
over to the yellow fever section I
was hardly ready before ambulance
drove in with Gen. Brooks Secretary
Dr Ames got a civilian from
New Orleans to come in with
us, we had 6 or 7 cases, later I was
sent over to Pyrotecnia to take care
of an officer I am not certain but
it seems to me the name was
Ludlow. Later I was sent to the same
place to care for Col. O'Reilly who
later became Surg General but he
he did not have yellow fever only suspect
6
sick only 3 or 4 day's after x-mass
I got typhoid fever when recovered
April 1900
I was given 30 day's furlough and
when I got back was sent out to
Quemados, day after reporting was
sent downtown to learn disinfecting
first on the wharf later on the big
barge that is how I louded in the
disinfection plant in Quemados

14) Four day's after Commissary

I asked Dr Ames if he couldn't

the Doctor came down with a

he told me to come outside as

to tell me when I got inside
the new man had put the screw top
7

down after I got Colby to beddI

happened and that I would manage

15) The first patient down there was
Packmaster Grayham, the same night
his wife came in, a day or two
after they left. Maj. Kean came in, the
day after Capt Hepburn came
8
the 5th patient was Mrs Blont or
Blunt wife of a Capt in 7th Col Cav.
she was in only two day's a suspect,
but her husband complained because
there was a man taking care of his
wife, his kick must have carried weight
because Maj. Stark or some one sent to
new Orleans after two immune
women who would care for lady patients
if we had any more, we never had,
so Dr Ames never put Mrs Gillen or
Lattie. to work Mrs Gillen had been
a cook and Lattie an office worker
When Dr Ames took sick Dr Pinto took his
place, two day's later Andrus came in
and Dr Pinto made the women move in
to building 1, they used to have 3, but
Andrus was put in 3, I had Folks and
Forbes in 4 and Dr Ames in 2 so I
was glad that Dr Pinto put them to work,
I can't remember if it was the same
day, or the day after Dr Ames was
moved up to the Hosp. and given a
room and Miss Vinifred Lewis took
9
care off him, the 3rd day Andrus
were sick Mrs Gillen came over
and asked me to come over and
help her tie Andrus to the bed
because he acted horribly I went
with her and Andrus was laying
across the bed naked feet on one
side and arms on the other I put
him back in beddand covered him
up I asked what the trouble was but
he couldn't answer only cried and
groned as if in pain I asked Mrs
Gillen if the Dr had seen him but
the Dr had not been in that day it was
2. P. M. I knew he had not been to see
my patients Andrus had been drinking
plenty of water Mrs Gillen said but
when I looked on the notes he had
not passed any urine for over eight
hours I asked Mrs Gillen if she had
tried to catherize him she said “oh
I couldn't do that” so I went over after
what I needed and drew 710. c. c. from
him, I went back at 7. P. M. and helped
10
him, went back again at 12 M. N.
but he was asleep and did not wake
him, at 3 A. M. or there about he urinated
without help. The fift day I was again
asked to come over I was told that there
was nothing the matter with Andrus
he was simply cranky, the boy couldn't
tell me his troubles he only cried, but
he was in great pain I could see that
so I brook quarrantine and race up to see
Dr Ames and told him that Andrus was
very sick and that Dr Pinto had not been
down there since the previous morning I
tried to tell the best I knew how he
acted but I couldn't described well
enough for the Dr. to diagnose his
trouble. I knew if Dr Ames could come
down Andrus would be all right so
I asked Dr Ames if there wasn't some
way he could come down, he said
I'm sick in bed myself, I suggested
that he let me get help and we would
carry him down to which he agreed
I can't remember if it was McCarthy
11
or Fanning I got hold of but he
came along and we went in and
picked up the bed and started out
when Miss Lewis came in (she was
out while I spoke to Dr Ames) she tried
to stop us so she could ask Maj. Stark
but we kept going Dr Ames wouldnt
let us walk over the litle bridge so
went around, the railroad cut McCarthy
put his end of beddinside of door I then
pushed Dr. Ames alongside of Andrus, the Dr.
found a carbuncle in his rectum (an ugly
looking thing) I brought a scalpel and
Dr Ames cut it, after geting the dirt out the
boy felt at ease. Dr Ames rested a litle and
we took him back. (Please read affidavit Miss
Lewis sent upon request) Maj Stark was
waiting! Miss Lewis say's Maj Stark was not
pleased no because for about 5 minutes
I got the worst calling down I ever had
for taking his patient out visiting
then he chased me out and told me
to get down to where I belonged.
The Majors anger was only temporary I
was the last person he operated on at
12
quemados he did that after he were
relieved. he operated on me at 10 A. M.
and left at one P. M. I did not have
a chance to thank him for his kindness
I have a letter from the War Dept stating
that Maj. Stark commended me to the
surg. Gen. Office for untiring attention
to duty while nursing yellow fever at
quemados I think it would have been
